Award.AwardTitle: From Clusters to Voids: Gas and Galaxy Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration: This project consists of three complementary observational efforts, intended to test the conceptual picture that galaxies may gain mass from their surroundings not by accretion of hot plasma that cools as it settles into the galaxy, but rather by accretion of gas that has already cooled in the intergalactic environment and remains cold as it flows into the galaxy, possibly on orderly streams with preferred directions. This idea has gained theoretical support in recent years through hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy formation; observational tests to be performed by the PI consist of radio observations, primarily in the 21 cm neutral hydrogen line, of (1) the outer parts of the nearby Virgo cluster of galaxies, (2) large volumes surrounding two distinctly different clusters at redshift z=0.2, and (3) galaxies located in extremely under-dense void regions. This work will exploit the newly enhanced capabilities of the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope (WSRT) in the Netherlands and the Expanded Very Large Array (EVLA) in the US. The new data will be combined with archived data to compare the morphologies, star forming properties, environments, and (where appropriate) locations within the clusters of galaxies with, and without, spatially extended cold gas. The observations will be compared against predictions made by high-resolution hydrodynamical simulations performed by a collaborator on the project; and the Virgo observations, in particular, will be made available to the research community through a website. The work will involve the participation of undergraduate and graduate students from under-represented groups, and will be highlighted in public presentations in schools and other venues.

From Clusters to Voids: Gas and Galaxy Evolution

One of the main questions in galaxy evolution today is: how
do galaxies get and lose their gas. In the last decade a renaissance has taken place in numerical simulations with a much more sophisticated approach to the physics of the gas than was previously possible. The prediction of the simulations is that the dominant growth mode of galaxies is through accretion  of gas.  The accretion rate depends on redshift, it is much more important at early times in the universe, on galaxy mass and on environment.  In the local universe this process is predicted to still take place in the lowest density environments and in the smallest galaxies. Observations indicate that the star formation rate has declined dramatically since z=1 and a major question is why.
In this project we addressed these issues by imaging the gas in
galaxies in a wide range of environments and comparing the results to
high quality hydrodynamical simulations.

The Void Galaxy Survey. Voids represents a unique environment for the study of galaxy evolution. The lower density should result in slower evolution of  galaxies. As accretion of cold gas is thought to still occur in the present in the smallest galaxies and lowest densities, voids may be the ideal place
to look for this. We did an imaging survey in neutral hydrogen of the deepest
underdensities of 60 voids selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.
Interestingly there are indeed no massive galaxies in the void. Most are
are small, star forming disk galaxies. The most interesting result is that
the neutral gas is generally very extended and many galaxies show signs that the gas has been disturbed recently, which could be evidence for infall.
We published two papers on the optical and gaseous properties of the
void galaxies in addition to several papers on detailed studies of selected
systems. A comparison with a high resolution hydrodynamic simulation of
the evolution of a void shows in general good agreement, except that the
simulations overpredict the amount of gas present.

Clusters of Galaxies. At the other extreme we studied the evolution of
galaxies in the highest density environments, the centers of
clusters. As follow up of our neutral hydrogen imaging survey of
galaxies in the Virgo cluster, we carried out detailed multiwavelength
studies of individual systems and combined these with modelling to
constrain the orbital histories of the galaxies.  Galaxies begin to
lose their gas in the outskirts of clusters and they get almost
completely stripped by ram pressure stripping by the hot gas as they
traverse the cluster.  They are likely to evolve into non star forming
S0 galaxies. In a study of two clusters at a redshift of z=0.2 we obtained spectra on thousands of galaxies and used those to define
the substructure of the clusters.  We then related neutral hydrogen
content and star formation activity to local galaxy density. We find
that galaxies are beginning to lose their gas in groups before they
fall into the clusters.
